subject: Real Estate
title: Cap Rates Explained
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Cap Rates Explained.

hook.text: A building earns $100,000 per year in rent. Is it worth $1 million or $2 million? The cap rate decides.

buildup.text: Cap rate = net operating income divided by property value. A 10% cap rate means $1M; 5% means $2M.

discovery.text: Lower cap rates mean investors accept less return, usually because they expect the property to appreciate.

twist.text: A 3% cap rate sounds terrible â€” until you realize Manhattan offices have traded at that level for decades.

climax.text: Cap rates compress when money is cheap and expand when risk rises. They're the heartbeat of commercial real estate.

punchline.text: One ratio tells you if a building is cheap or expensive.

quiz.question: What does a lower cap rate generally indicate?
options: The property is in poor condition
